title: Seaton Sluice Walks

nearby.description: Souter Lighthouse and Whitburn Coastal Park

images.title: wfmillar / Seaton Sluice Harbour
images.caption: Seaton Sluice Harbour. The bridge on the left carries the A193. The sands and dunes stretch to Blyth

images.title: Joan Sykes / Beach at Seaton Sluice
images.caption: Beach at Seaton Sluice. Looking at the jetty, lighthouse and windfarm at Blyth on a clear day.

images.title: Michael Preston / Low water in Collywell Bay
images.caption: Low water in Collywell Bay

images.title: peter cowling / Crag Point, Hartley Bay.
images.caption: Crag Point, Hartley Bay. Cliff fall of upper Crag Point sandstone obscuring Lower Crag Point sandstone at base of cliff. Note fault to left, downthrow north, showing contrast between sandstone and shales.

images.title: Oliver Dixon / Hartley Bay
images.caption: Hartley Bay. Looking down to the beach from the coastal footpath. St Mary's Island can be seen in the distance

images.title: Andrew Curtis / Causeway to St Mary's Island
images.caption: Causeway to St Mary's Island. The notice warns that the route is tidal and subject to fast flooding.

images.title: Lighthouse on St. Mary's Island by Derek Voller, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Lighthouse on St. Mary's Island

images.title: Antonia / Across the Green
images.caption: Across the Green. Looking across the green at Seaton Sluice with the distinctive Kings Arms to the right

description: This pretty village sits in a lovely spot on the Northumberland coast near Whitley Bay and Blyth. This walk takes you along the sea front to the wildlife rich St Mary's Nature Reserve. You can start the walk at the Seaton Sluice Car Park next to the beach at the northern end of the village. From here you can head south past Rocky Island, Colywell Bay and Crag Point before coming to St Mary's Nature Reserve next to St Mary's Island. The area is a popular bird watching site with the island itself also accessible at low tide by crossing the causeway. Here you can visit the photogenic lighthouse and enjoy fine views towards Whitley Bay. The route runs for about 2 miles with the option of extending it by continuing on to Whitley Bay where you could pick up the Whitley Bay to Tynemouth Walk .

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: The Kings Arms is in a good location next to the harbour at postcode NE26 4RD. The friendly cliff top pub serves good quality food and has a fine selection of drinks.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: One of the highlights of the area is the National Trust's Seaton Delaval Hall. The early 18th century Georgian mansion has an interesting history and is surrounded by some lovely gardens. You can find the property at The Avenue with postcode NE26 4QR. To the north is the town of Blyth where there are some nice trails along the beach and River Blyth Estuary.

display_address: Fountain Head Car Park, Links Road, Seaton Valley, Seaton Sluice, Northumberland, North East, England, NE26 4JY, United Kingdom
